entries.author: buddy_burden
entries.text: I seem to always like the articles of Buddy Burden, even when he writes about a questionable feature of Perl. In recent versions of perl you don't always need to manually de-reference references to hashes and arrays that can either make your code cleaner (no @{ } or %{ } around some snippets) but it might be ambiguous. It is certainly good to be aware of these features and decide if you will accept, encourage or ban their use in your code-base.
entries.title: Is This a Hashref Which I See Before Me? (no, wait, it's an arrayref ...)

entries.author: reini_urban
entries.text: The p2 (also known as Perl 5+6=11) project of Reini Urban is trying to create a bridge between Perl 5 and Perl 6. Compiling Perl 5 code to run on the Perl 6 run-time.
entries.title: First p2 milestone passed: parse 50% of perl5

entries.author: rob_hoelz
entries.text: In which Rob Hoelz explains what is the difference between undef $x; and $x = undef; and how perl handles hashes internally.
entries.title: Perl 5 Internals - Part Three

entries.author: timm_murray
entries.text: While probably you won't get a lot of daily usage out of this module it is certainly fascinating how Timm Murray from the Wumpus Cave explains the problems with associative arrays, (also known as hashes) and how Tree::Trie could solve all the problems. If we actually noticed that there are problems.
entries.title: What's a Trie, and Why Should You Care?

entries.author: david_golden
entries.text: Especially interesting for CPAN authors who would like to read their POD in a web browser, before they upload the module to PAUSE. David Golden create a short script that would turn POD into HTML and then open your default browser to that file. Even if you don't need this service, the script is a nice example of using Path::Tiny, Pod::Simple::XHTML, and Browser::Open.
entries.title: Previewing POD before shipping

entries.author: neil_bowers
entries.text: If you want to research CPAN, you'll soon need to go over all the distributions available there. Neil Bowers has been working on the tool to show the CPAN modules that are good candidates for adoption. Now he shows us how he iterate over all the CPAN distributions using PAUSE::Packages.
entries.title: Iterating over all dists on CPAN

entries.text: Traversing a directory structure is not a very complex thing, but writing it again and again is boring. So why not use a module with a great interface?
entries.title: Finding files in a directory tree using Perl

entries.text: Do you know how to create constants in Perl? Hint: it is probably not the constant pragma.
